Award.AwardTitle: A-DRIVE: Affordable Design by Realistic Interactions for Virtual Explorations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to develop a new class of design scenarios, interaction and manipulation paradigms for design using sketching in 2D and natural gestures enabled by affordable depth sensing cameras. These natural interactions will transform human gestures to tangible shapes. Gestures will also be developed for 2D and 3D interaction with the created shapes. This natural gesture-based interaction paradigm will enable exploratory processes typical during brainstorming and support creative design exploration for sketching in 2D on real world surfaces, physical world to virtual transformation of 3D objects, and assembly with no training. A computational foundation and algorithms for accurate creation of sketches and manipulation using gestures in 2D will be developed while exploring design scenarios using virtual construction kit ideas and design assembly scenarios. We will develop a theory and scientific basis for Human-Computer-Human Interaction and architectural framework for design collaboration.

Since the natural expression of shapes is the essence of creativity and visual thinking, it will be useful in design processes, especially in early stages. The new design concepts, methods and tools to support transformative design thinking will create new affordances for designs and if successful transform early design processes. This award will also introduce effective design learning in workshops to assist K-12 STEM education. Over the long term, the research, education, and dissemination efforts for natural design in 2D and 3D will enhance the creative design capacity. It would also enable any common person, including those that are young, to communicate and prototype design ideas directly in 3D space that have potential to fundamentally alter design paradigms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Summary:

 

A-DRIVE explored new and exciting virtual design-creation environments that include natural pen-and-touch based design sketching, in-the-air hand gesture based construction of digital design models, use of “ordinary” surfaces (e.g. walls and tables) as digital design media, and the ability to quickly generate design prototypes and rapidly iterate them. Due to their ease of use, the design environments make complex design modeling accessible to novice users without formal training in design. This can be mainly attributed to the new forms of human-computer interactions and communications introduced by our work, which aims to make design modeling intuitive and relatable to natural human actions/experiences. We also anticipate that our 3D interaction techniques and design tools will make the process of design much more engaging and enhance user experience in terms of enjoyment and creative inspiration. The results of our user studies indicate that our work not only impacts design but can also be extended to other domains such as architectural modeling, interactive 3D data inspection/analysis, medical practices, education, and manufacturing. With rapid developments in 3D technologies and immersive VR/AR displays, we also anticipate our work to provide a basis for developing natural interactions amenable towards such media.

To this end, we presented six novel interfaces catering to our approach towards design modeling and interactions. Here, ZPots allowed users (including kids) to create a wide variety of pottery designs in a digital medium, using suggestive hand gestures (similar to how one would make pottery in the real world), without having to deal with the mess. Similarly, Planar Possessions allows users to utilize ordinary physical objects (e.g. a cardboard box) as tangible input devices to control virtual 3D objects. This capability was demonstrated in Proto-TAI, where novice users can utilize a cardboard cutout as a physical controller for holding and assembling planar shapes to construct complex 3D planar shape designs. In Realfusion, we showed that users can not only utilize physical objects as controllers, but also use their form as building blocks of new design models. To better inform the interactions used in the design environments, we developed Gesture Analyzer and MotionFlow, which provide us (and other interaction designers) a rapid way to visualize, study, and analyze user gestures and motions associated with different activities. These tools allowed us to ensure intuitiveness of the design interactions and helped make them as natural to the users as possible.
